description: From Middle English palate, from Latin palātum (“roof of the mouth, palate”), perhaps of Etruscan origin.

definitionGroups.group: (anatomy) The roof of the mouth, separating the cavities of the mouth and nose in vertebrates. [from 14th c.]

entries.meaning: (zoology) A part associated with the mouth of certain invertebrates, somewhat analagous to the palate of vertebrates. [from 20th c.]
(entomology, rare) The hypopharynx of an insect. [from 19th c.]
(botany) A projection in the throat of certain bilabiate flowers as the snapdragon. [from 18th c.]
(cooking, historical) The palate of an animal, as an item of food. [from 17th c.]
(figuratively) A person's ability to distinguish between and appreciate different flavors. [from 14th c.]
(figuratively) Mental relish; a liking or affinity for something. [from 15th c.]
Taste or flavour, especially with reference to wine or other alcoholic drinks. [from 20th c.]

verbs.description: palate (third-person singular simple present palates, present participle palating, simple past and past participle palated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, nonstandard) To relish; to find palatable.
